user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BSP_ConsoleSetMode_Impl:
```c
void OS_BSP_ConsoleSetMode_Impl(uint32 ModeBits)
{
    char param[32];

    if (OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.EnableTermControl)
    {
        if (ModeBits == OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL)
        {
            OS_BSP_ExecTput("sgr0", NULL);
        }
        else
        {
            if ((ModeBits & OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_HIGHLIGHT) == 0)
            {
                /* no highlight (standout) text */
                OS_BSP_ExecTput("rmso", NULL);
            }
            else
            {
                /* set highlight (standout) text */
                OS_BSP_ExecTput("smso", NULL);
            }

            snprintf(param, sizeof(param), "%d", OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_TO_ANSICOLOR(ModeBits));
            OS_BSP_ExecTput("setaf", param);
        }
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
OS_BSP_ExecTput("setaf", param);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: If the function OS_BSP_ExecTput is declared to accept non-const pointers (for example: void OS_BSP_ExecTput(char *cap, char *arg);) then this call violates MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13. Neither the string literal "setaf" nor the local buffer param are modified by the call, so the parameters should be declared as const-qualified pointers (e.g. const char *cap, const char *arg). Passing read-only data to non-const pointer parameters therefore breaches the rule.
